intro: Scrophularia armeniaca, commonly known as Armenian figwort, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of the Caucasus and Turkey. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, lance-shaped leaves with hairy surfaces. The plant produces showy, two-lipped flowers in shades of purple or pink, often arranged in terminal spikes. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in alpine or subalpine habitats. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal uses, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens and traditional herbal medicine.
